urn:contentItem:6GNJ-3DY3-RS5H-31XH-00000-00Climate change has fueled forest fires in Spain and Portugal2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisClimate change has fueled forest fires in Spain and Portugal


Scientists claim that devastating fires this summer in Europe were 40 times more likely ??due to rising global temperatures from burning fossil fuels.Intense forest fires that ravaged large areas of Spain and Portugal this summer in Europe - claiming at least 8 lives and forcing the evacuation of tens of thousands of people - were massively fueled by climate change, claims a new report published on Thursday (04/09).


The document states that climate change - mainly driven by the burning of oil, gas and coal - has made the weather conditions that fueled forest fires 40 times more frequent and 30% more intense. The analysis was carried out by World Weather Attribution, a group of international scientists who study the role of global warming in extreme weather events.
The magnitude of the fires has been "staggering", said Clair Barnes, one of the authors of the report and a researcher at the Environmental Policy Center at Imperial College London. "Hotter, drier and more flammable conditions are becoming more severe with climate change and are giving rise to fires of unprecedented intensity."
Climate change makes fires more frequent and intense
The forest fires, which started at the end of July and raged for weeks, burned more than 380,000 hectares in Spain and 260,000 hectares in Portugal. Together, they accounted for two thirds of the land burned in Europe, which this year broke records by exceeding 1 million hectares, an area larger than the island of Cyprus.
Although forest fires are a natural annual occurrence, intense drought and rising temperatures are creating a hot, dry and windy climate, which makes them burn faster, longer and with more ferocity. In Europe, as elsewhere in the world, they are becoming more frequent, intense and widespread.
The rapid analysis examined meteorological observations from the region, including the ten hottest consecutive days ever recorded in Spain and which preceded the fires. The conclusion was that climate change has made the Spanish heatwave 3 degrees Celsius hotter and 200 times more likely to occur.
In a world without climate change, heatwaves of similar intensity would be expected less frequently, about every 2,500 years. Today, however - with current warming levels of 1.3°C - they are expected every 13 years, say the scientists.
Fires more difficult to fight
This summer in the northern hemisphere, Spain made its first request for international support to help fight forest fires. The European Civil Protection Mechanism, a system set up by the EU to provide disaster response to member states, has also been contacted by Greece, Bulgaria, Albania and Montenegro for help in fighting fires.
"Forest fires are reaching new extremes in Spain and Portugal," said Theodore Keeping, one of the report's authors and a researcher at Imperial College London's Environmental Policy Center. "Increasingly, firefighters are working in chaotic and unpredictable conditions, fighting fires that behave in ways never seen before."
Keeping also pointed out that intense forest fires can create their own winds, which spread flames longer and can cause flying embers which, in turn, end up sparking new fires nearby.
The steep terrain that characterizes northern Portugal and the northwestern region of Galicia in Spain, where the fires were concentrated, made fighting them even more difficult, said Ricardo Trigo, one of the authors of the report and an associate professor in the Department of Geophysics, Geographical Engineering and Energy at the University of Lisbon.
Forest management is key to prevention
Keeping adds that these areas are among the most prone to forest fires in Europe because they receive significant amounts of rain between October and March - allowing a lot of vegetation to grow, which then turns into fuel during the dry, hot summers.
The report emphasizes the importance of vegetation control in areas regularly impacted by forest fires, highlighting how the movement of populations from rural to urban areas has left many forests and farms without proper management and covered in dry vegetation.
With firefighting resources depleted, experts argue that the focus needs to shift to prevention measures, such as sustainable land management and improving the resilience of forests.
Methods for this include thinning and properly spacing trees and reducing undergrowth through controlled burns. Other alternatives include introducing more grazing animals, such as cattle and goats, which eat the dry shrubs that serve as fuel for the flames.
Abandoning monocultures and introducing firebreaks or fire protection zones can also help.
Abandoning fossil fuels is an urgent necessity
So far this year, forest fires in the EU have released 38 million tons of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas responsible for global warming. This puts the continent on course to break CO2 emission records by 2025.
Smoke from forest fires also has a significant impact on health, with particles emitted capable of entering the lungs and bloodstream. Recent studies have linked forest fire smoke to 1.53 million deaths a year worldwide.
Experts in the report also warn that the fires in Spain and Portugal are a sign of things to come as temperatures continue to rise. They therefore emphasize the urgency of stopping the burning of fossil fuels.
"The forest fires in Europe show that 1.3°C of warming today is already incredibly dangerous," said Friederike Otto, one of the authors of the report and professor of climate science at the Environmental Policy Center at Imperial College London. "Without a faster transition away from fossil fuels, we could reach 3 degrees Celsius this century. Forest fires at that level would be catastrophic."

urn:contentItem:6FMT-PDN3-RRRH-S0T7-00000-00New Jersey Wildfire Containment Map as Officials Warn Blaze Could Spread2025-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisNew Jersey Wildfire Containment Map as Officials Warn Blaze Could SpreadAnna Skinner

The Jones Road fire has grown to 12,000 acres in size and is 35 percent contained as of Wednesday afternoon.

A massive wildfire burning across Ocean County, New Jersey,has consumed 12,000 acres and could become the state's largest wildfire in two decades. Officials said Wednesday that the Jones Road wildfire is 35 percent contained, as emergency crews continue efforts to secure the area and prevent further spread.

The fire, which ignited around 12:30 p.m. Tuesday in the Greenwood Forest Wildlife Management Area in Barnegat Township, quickly spread into Lacey and Ocean townships.

Newsweek reached out to the New Jersey Forest Fire Service by phone and by email for comment.

Why It Matters

The scale and speed of the Jones Road fire have triggered widespread evacuations, road closures and power outages, impacting thousands of New Jersey residents. Environmental Commissioner Shawn LaTourette warned during a Wednesday morning press conference that the blaze "could very well end up being the largest wildfire in New Jersey in 20 years," citing dry conditions and unpredictable winds.

A state of emergency was declared for Ocean County early Wednesday by Acting Governor Tahesha Way, with more than 5,000 people temporarily evacuated and more than 25,000 residents losing power.

What to Know

As of Wednesday afternoon, the Jones Road fire had burned roughly 12,000 acres, threatening 20 structures and destroying at least one commercial building. Roads, including stretches of the Garden State Parkway and U.S. Route 9, were closed for hours, contributing to significant traffic delays across the region.

Full containment is expected to occur at 15,410 acres, according to the most recent map shared by the New Jersey Forest Fire Service.

Power was cut deliberately in some areas to protect emergency crews from downed lines, and shelters were opened for displaced residents at Southern Regional and Manchester Township high schools. Evacuation orders were lifted on Wednesday as containment improved, though authorities continue to monitor fire lines closely.

The blaze's ignition source remains under investigation. No injuries have been reported.

Smoke from the fire has blanketed parts of southern New Jersey, prompting air quality alerts.Though Wednesday's winds are forecast to be lighter, the area has faced prolonged dry weather since the fall, creating ripe conditions for fire spread.

Firefighters have implemented backfiring tactics—intentionally burning areas ahead of the main fire to remove fuel—and deployed fire engines, bulldozers, and ground crews. The Forest Fire Service said another update would be provided at 4 p.m.

What People Are Saying

New Jersey Forest Fire Service in a post on X, formerly Twitter: "New Jersey Forest Fire Service is making progress containing a wildfire burning in Ocean & Lacey Townships, Ocean County."

An air quality official with New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection told Newsweek in a statement: "Light winds are expected to prevail, potentially keeping transport levels low and aiding in containment of the wildfire. Due to this being an active fire, we are monitoring the conditions and will update if necessary. The next chance of rain is this weekend, which may help improve air quality."

What Happens Next

Weather conditions in the coming days—particularly the potential for rain—could assist firefighters, but crews are preparing for a multi-day response. Residents are urged to avoid the affected areas and adhere to any new alerts or evacuation notices.

urn:contentItem:6FP9-M463-RW7G-B0VC-00000-00Chinese Academy of Sciences Researchers Further Understanding of Remote Sensing (Adaptive Early Wildfire Monitoring Based on Spatiotemporal Prediction and Himawari 8/9)2025-04-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - REMOTE SENSINGChinese Academy of Sciences Researchers Further Understanding of Remote Sensing (Adaptive Early Wildfire Monitoring Based on Spatiotemporal Prediction and Himawari 8/9)


2025 APR 30 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- A new study on remote sensing is now available. According to news reporting out of Beijing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "The rapid advancement of deep learning (DL) technology significantly enhances early forest fire detection methods."


Financial supporters for this research include Second Tibetan Plateau Scientific Expedition And Research Program; National Key Research And Development Program of China.
The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Chinese Academy of Sciences: "However, traditional approaches often rely on fixed thresholds and supervised learning techniques, which may fail to account for the complex spatiotemporal dynamics associated with forest fire events. To overcome this limitation, an adaptive DL model is proposed and specifically designed for early forest fire monitoring. This model integrates Stacking ConvLSTM to forecast mid-infrared brightness temperatures and employs a nonparametric dynamic thresholding method based on Otsu's algorithm for spatiotemporal anomaly detection, facilitating the identification of potential hotspots. By effectively capturing complex dependencies within spatiotemporal dimensions, this method improves detection accuracy. Furthermore, high-confidence early fire points are determined through dual-band analysis and land cover detection. Comparative experiments utilizing Himawari-8/9 satellite data reveal that the proposed method outperforms traditional techniques as well as the latest temporal methods, achieving an accuracy of 0.995, precision of 0.985, recall of 0.946, and an F1 score of 0.965."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "In addition, our method demonstrates an average fire detection delay of just 7 min and an average runtime of 71 s, underscoring its effectiveness in early forest fire detection. This approach serves as a robust tool for enhancing forest fire monitoring systems, offering significant implications for reducing response times and mitigating fire-related damages."
For more information on this research see: Adaptive Early Wildfire Monitoring Based on Spatiotemporal Prediction and Himawari 8/9. IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing, 2025,18():9396-9408. The publisher for IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing is IEEE.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1109/JSTARS.2025.3554892.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Zekun Xu, Aerospace Information Research Institute (AIR), Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Zhaoming Zhang, Guojin He, Shuaizhang Zhang, Tengfei Long, Guizhou Wang.
Keywords for this news article include: Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, People's Republic of China, Asia, Remote Sensing, Technology.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC

SECTION 2 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

2.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

Weyerhaeuser Company has consistently demonstrated its commitment to sustainable forestry and community development through strategic investments and philanthropic efforts. Recently, Weyerhaeuser made headlines with its land donation for the Row River wildfire substation, exemplifying its leadership in wildfire protection and emergency services partnerships. This initiative underscores Weyerhaeuser's dedication to wildfire mitigation and response infrastructure, crucial in safeguarding forests and nearby communities.

In West Virginia, Weyerhaeuser's investment strategy is robust, epitomized by a $1 million community investment in Buckhannon. This investment is set to bolster rural economic development and enhance Weyerhaeuser's community grants and support efforts. Highlighting its philanthropic endeavors, Weyerhaeuser's charitable giving focuses on corporate social responsibility, revered by the Buckhannon community for fostering sustainable forestry.

Through such initiatives, including timberland and forestland donations, Weyerhaeuser maintains a steadfast commitment to land stewardship, enhancing community resilience, and ensuring a sustainable future for generations. Weyerhaeuser's overarching goal remains clear: elevating community development while ensuring the sustainability of critical ecosystems.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

May 22: Weyerhaeuser Acquiring High-Quality Timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia

Capitalizing on unique off-market opportunity to further enhance Southern Timberlands portfolio with highly productive and strategically located acreage

SEATTLE, May 22, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced an agreement to acquire approximately 117,000 acres of high-quality timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia from Roanoke Timberlands LLC, a subsidiary of Roseburg Forest Products, for $375 million. Comprised of mature, highly productive timberlands, the acreage will be well-integrated with existing Weyerhaeuser timberland and mill operations in North Carolina, will expand the company's footprint into attractive markets in southeastern Virginia and will offer substantial alternative value opportunities. The acquisition is expected to deliver immediate and sustained portfolio-leading cash flows within the company's Southern Timberlands business.

Key attributes of the acquisition:

Located in strong and growing sawlog and fiber markets in the U.S. South Primarily fee ownership with 81 percent planted pine acreage, strong site productivity and favorable all-weather logging operability Mature planted pine age class expected to produce an average annual harvest of 7.4 tons per acre (or 860,000 tons) over the first five years Expected to deliver an average annual timber free cash flow yield of 5.1 percent over the first five years Significant optionality to capture additional upside from real estate, natural climate solutions and natural resource opportunities "These are exceptional timberlands, and we're excited and well-positioned to capitalize on this unique off-market opportunity," said Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our unmatched timber holdings and have remained disciplined in our approach to growing the value of our timberlands - including through strategically targeted private transactions like the one we're announcing today.

SEATTLE, May 21, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced it has reached an agreement to sell its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group, owners of Gorman Bros.Lumber Ltd., a family-owned wood products manufacturer headquartered in West Kelowna, B.C. The purchase price is approximately $120 million CAD in cash, which includes Weyerhaeuser's manufacturing facility, all associated timber license assets in British Columbia and the value of working capital, which will be subject to customary purchase price adjustments at closing.

Weyerhaeuser and Gorman Group have a long-standing relationship in Canada. Gorman Bros.Lumber is currently the Princeton mill's largest customer, and Gorman Group has operated in Canada for more than 75 years, with offices and facilities in B.C. and Washington state.

"We are grateful to all the dedicated employees who contributed to the success of our Princeton operations over the years," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer for Weyerhaeuser. "The community has always been incredibly welcoming and supportive of our mill and people, and it was important for us to sell to a local buyer with deep roots in the region. Gorman has been a great customer and strategic partner, and we believe this will be a seamless transition that will position the mill for future success in a challenging operating environment - providing long-term certainty for the mill and the broader community."

"Weyerhaeuser's Princeton operation will be a natural fit with the Gorman Group," says Nick Arkle, chief executive officer of the Gorman Group. "We've had a strong connection to the Princeton operation for many years, and we know firsthand the skill, commitment and quality that define its team.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

urn:contentItem:6GJB-GT13-RVF9-508X-00000-00Other Views: Town halls showcase Oregonians' resiliency2025-08-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSOther Views: Town halls showcase Oregonians' resiliencyThe Observer, La Grande, Ore.

At my recent open-to-all town halls in Sherman, Wheeler, Gilliam, Morrow and Wallowa counties, I heard firsthand how the same challenges keep surfacing across rural Oregon.

These five Eastern Oregon counties have a combined population of just 25,000 Oregonians. But I’m not just the senator for Oregon’s big cities — I’m proud to represent all of Oregon. Each town hall reinforces one key theme: Every Oregonian’s voice counts, no matter where they live.

Across these Eastern Oregon counties, people asked smart and focused questions about how decisions made by congressional Republicans in Washington, D.C., are creating real hardships in their communities thousands of miles away.

From health care cuts that threaten to close rural hospitals, to U.S. Department of Agriculture reorganizations that eliminate local agricultural expertise, to arbitrary grant cancellations that undermine fire prevention efforts — every issue I heard reflected the devastating local impact of distant political decisions that prioritize ideology over rural Oregon’s needs.

In Wheeler County, Fossil Mayor Carol MacInnes spoke about how that tiny community is grappling with a $30,000 debt and deteriorating water infrastructure — problems worsened by Republican cuts to rural infrastructure programs and their resistance to new federal investment in small communities.

No town in Oregon should be placed in a position where it must choose between basic services and financial stability. I committed to introducing legislation specifically for rural water infrastructure to help communities like Fossil.

One issue that dominated every conversation in eastern Oregon was health care. And let’s face it, it’s an issue that gets personal really fast.

At one stop, I was shocked to learn three-quarters of a mental health center’s clients face roadblocks accessing Medicaid, thanks to Republican proposals to slash Medicaid funding and impose work requirements that create huge bureaucratic barriers. At another stop, a hospital CEO cautioned his facility could close because of proposed cuts to Medicaid funding that supports rural hospitals. This will suddenly strand 7,000 people without local health care. When a hospital closes, an entire community suffers.

Agriculture was another big issue.

A wheat grower told me prices are now essentially what they were in the 1970s, while costs have skyrocketed due to various factors including trade uncertainties and input cost inflation. The recent reorganization of the USDA — based on incoherent and inane cuts — threatens research partnerships that help our farmers stay competitive globally by eliminating regional offices and forcing consolidation that reduces local expertise.

I also heard how rural veterans are getting a raw deal.

I met a woman whose 94-year-old mother has been waiting since January for spousal benefits from the Veterans Administration. In another example, veterans must drive four hours round trip to access medications because the Veterans Administration recently decided it won’t ship locally to rural clinics.j lm

Just as frustrating was hearing about a forest fire prevention grant suddenly canceled without explanation by the so-called Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), Trump’s unaccountable firing of essential workers and slashing of key services. That’s just the kind of arbitrary baloney that makes rural Oregonians lose faith in their government.

Yet, I was also pleased to see incredible resilience among Oregonians. A rural pharmacist is innovating ways to serve his community while fighting predatory insurance practices. Renewable energy projects are providing crucial second incomes for farm families facing economic uncertainty — projects Republicans tried to eliminate but I battled to protect.

I’m taking immediate steps based on what I heard: demanding action on rural hospital funding, trying to restore forest and water grants, reforming pharmacy benefit managers, and pressing officials about VA failures while working to protect Social Security.

My town halls are democracy in action. After more than 1,100 of these meetings, real solutions come from real conversations with real Oregonians tackling real problems.

urn:contentItem:6GKX-RJG3-RT8C-R05C-00000-00Thunder Mountain hosts action-packed races2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19Thunder Mountain hosts action-packed racesRuth Lloyd

Thunder Mountain Speedway’s track saw some action on Aug. 23 with the Memorial Race.

It was a small crowd out to watch the cars, but those who came got a few different special treats, and we’re not referring to the ice cream available on site to help cool the crowd.

The Central Cariboo Search and Rescue team performed a demonstration extraction and drivers pulled up for a meet and greet with spectators, giving them the opportunity to sit behind the wheel of a race car. There were also some crashes, creating some thrilling race action.

It was another tough break for Olivia Finamore, after she was struck by Chip Schick in the hornet class heat.

This was the second time Finamore’s custom paint job was personalized by a fellow racer, and she had to head straight for the pits after this one, with her steering compromised.

Initially, Finamore feared she wouldn’t be able to finish the night, but her handy husband and some helpful fellow racers with a key part got her back on the track and ready to go for another round by the end of the meet and greet.

Luckily for Finamore, there was a bit more time to work on her car while Central Cariboo Search and Rescue (CCSAR) completed a demonstration vehicle extraction. Harley Astleford took one for the team by crashing a PT Cruiser into a minivan in the centre of the track. The extraction crew opened up the cruiser’s hood, disconnected power to the vehicle, then exposed and cut away the top of the vehicle, allowing the rescuers to lift the entire roof off and away. They then slid in a spine board to show how they could fully extract the injured person in case of an actual crash.

Another collision happened later in the night’s action-packed events, after the Tribune had left the scene.

A post on the Thunder Mountain Speedway Facebook page by Loren Hollett celebrated the night of action with a shout out to the CCSAR crews and said it was the first night of racing under the new 77Motorsports banner, showing photos of the damage to their car after the night’s events.

His son Asher Hollett, the car’s driver, was in a final add-on event, after the main events were done. Having won third in the main event in his class, Asher went for another 25 laps, but lost control at one point. “The car got a little bit snakey,” said Loren. The car flipped one and a half times, landing on its hood. He said those who left early missed out in catching the crash.

But the roll cage did it’s job and thanks to the extensive safety equipment, Asher himself was apparently none the worse for wear. The same could not be said for his car, and the track tow truck had to give it a little help to get it onto the trailer. Loren said the damage appears to be limited to the front end, and they hope it isn’t anything structural.

Despite the car looking quite crunched, Wayne posted a promise the team plans to make the final race of the season.

“With a lot of blood sweat and perhaps a few expletives, 77 will be at the track for the season-ender September 27,” he wrote. He said the offers of help from the Thunder Mountain community have been amazing.

“It won’t be pretty, but it’ll be up and running,” he said.

Being the Memorial Race, a black flag lap was done to honour the three former Thunder Mountain racers who had died in the past year:Karl Seibert, Don Urquhart, and Earl Thomas.

Racers who took home trophies include:Emily Thomas who won the Hornet class main event and had the fastest time in Hornet class, Sage Howlett who won one for the Hornet Dash event and second in the Hornet main event, Asher Hollett was third in the Hornet class main event, Mikey Garcia clocked the fastest time for the Legends class and won the main event, Jay McKeown was second in Legends main, Dagon Spooner was third in the Legend class main event, Brett Melville was first in the Thunder class dash, won the main event and also had the fastest time in Thunder class and Sheldon Emerson was second in Thunder main.

One of the most exciting parts of the night for some may have been the celebrations after the races when fireworks began nearby at the Dirt Riders Association motorcross track area. But shortly after they began, so did a forest fire.

Those still in the pit area at Thunder Mountain quickly called in the fire with the help of their Starlink connection, as there is no cell service at the Thunder Mountain Speedway or motocross track.

Emergency crews responded and the fire was listed it as under control on Monday, Aug. 25.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-M193-S8S1-M410-00000-00Taiwan: Firefighter Safety Upgrade - Ministry of the Interior to Fully Implement Accident Safety Officer System in 20262025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisTaiwan: Firefighter Safety Upgrade - Ministry of the Interior to Fully Implement Accident Safety Officer System in 2026

Key Highlights:

* The MOI has approved 24 mid-term plans with a total budget of NT$28.5 billion to promote firefighter safety, including the replacement of firefighting equipment and introduction of AI occupational safety management.

* The accident safety officer system will be fully implemented, with a focus on hazard identification, self-protection skills, and risk awareness in firefighter training.

* The NFA will conduct multiple sessions of high-level cadre training, disaster relief safety education, and accident safety officer special classes to comprehensively enhance firefighter rescue safety.

Original Press Release:

Aug. 28 -- Ministry of the Interior, R. O. C. (Taiwan) issued the following news release:

The Ministry of the Interior arranged for the Fire Department to report on the "Accident Safety Officer Training Results and Subsequent Handling Directions" at the Ministry Council Meeting today (28). Parliamentary Secretary Ma Shiyuan said that the safety of firefighters on duty is the most important policy goal of the Ministry of the Interior. In order to comprehensively improve the work safety and health protection of firefighters, the Ministry of the Interior will fully promote the establishment of accident safety officers in all counties and cities next year (115). In addition to guiding fire agencies at all levels to implement the configuration of accident safety officers, the Fire Department will continue to strengthen accident site safety education and training and plan overseas training opportunities. In addition, it will train firefighters to strengthen hazard identification, self-protection skills and risk awareness. At the same time, through system implementation, professional training and cultural promotion, every firefighter can go on duty safely and return home safely.

The Ministry of the Interior stated that in recent years, numerous firefighter deaths have occurred both domestically and internationally, including the Ming Yang International factory explosion in Pingtung County, the Qingkonghui fire in Hsinchu City, the drowning rescue incident at Guangxing Bridge in New Taipei City, as well as the forest fire in South Korea and the building fire in Osaka, Japan. These incidents have resulted in firefighter casualties, demonstrating the increasing risks faced by firefighters. To address this challenge, the Fire Department implemented the "Medium-Term Plan to Establish Firefighter Occupational Safety and Health Operations" between 2015 and 2019. This plan comprehensively enhanced safety through systems, organization, and training, including the deployment of dedicated incident safety officers and a real-time risk monitoring and reporting mechanism.

The Ministry of the Interior emphasized that to safeguard firefighters' safety, the central government has approved 24 medium-term plans with a total budget of NT$28.5 billion. These plans will promote multi-faceted reforms, including the replacement of firefighting equipment, improvements to firefighting buildings, the introduction of AI-based occupational safety management, and enhanced disaster relief capabilities. Furthermore, the plan will increase firefighting manpower and comprehensively strengthen grassroots firefighting capabilities. However, in addition to equipment, promoting systems and a safety culture are also crucial. Incident safety officers, within the on-site command system, are responsible for identifying and assessing hazards and have the authority to suspend or terminate dangerous operations, playing a key role in ensuring firefighter safety.

The Ministry of the Interior stated that the Fire Department has established an Incident Safety Officer system and established safety guidelines and regulations for various disasters. These regulations mandate that firefighters immediately initiate life-saving operations upon arrival at a disaster scene, establish an on-site disaster relief command post, and incorporate the role of safety officer into their teams. Furthermore, to strengthen fire rescue safety management, the Fire Department revised the "Key Points for Fire Scene Command and Rescue Operations of Fire Agencies," specifying that safety staff or safety officers must be assigned based on the severity of the fire. These officers will be responsible for monitoring on-site hazards, conducting risk assessments, and providing timely warnings to commanders. This revision will take effect on January 1, 2021.

The Ministry of the Interior further stated that the Fire Department is also consulting with international safety officer systems and continuously promoting related training and institutional planning. The department will fully implement the Incident Safety Officer system, concurrently conducting multiple levels of senior officer training, disaster relief safety education, and specialized Incident Safety Officer training programs to comprehensively enhance firefighter disaster relief safety. Furthermore, in July of this year, firefighters were sent to the United States to participate in Incident Safety Officer training at the National Fire Academy, bringing back international experience. The department also plans to invite American lecturers to Taiwan in November to provide training, assisting county and city fire departments in establishing safety officer systems tailored to their specific jurisdictions.

urn:contentItem:6GKV-69J3-RS30-X3TM-00000-00Amid Canada's tough wildfire season, opinions split over use of volunteers and reservists 2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWS, Oceania latest & CANADA NEWSAmid Canada's tough wildfire season, opinions split over use of volunteers and reservists 

As Canada grapples with its second-worst wildfire season on record, could more volunteer firefighters and wildfire reservists be helpful in addressing out-of-control fires in the future? 

The answer may eventually emerge in Alberta as that province launched a wildfire reservist program in 2024.

The provincial government's program allows anyone to sign up to help fight fires. Forestry Minister Todd Loewen said those who are 18 and older who sign up get a day and a half of training and undergo a fitness test. They can help out in firefighter camps or work on hot spots. Reservists get paid during training and if they are deployed.

Sean Gurnsey said he plans to sign up next year.

"The general feeling is, hey, if we can help somebody not to go through their worst day, I mean, that would be a good thing for us to do," he said.

In May 2023, wildfires started to burn near Gurnsey's property in rural Alberta. He didn't think twice about jumping into action even though he had no firefighting experience. He and his family used what they had to fight the flames approaching the family property north of Peers, Alta., roughly 175 kilometres west of Edmonton.

"We were trying to fight it with whatever we had - dirt, a couple skid steers, pails, five-gallon pails," Gurnsey said.

The property was saved thanks in part to a contingent of relatives and neighbours who stepped up to help.

"It was a 24-hour period before we saw official firefighters," Gurnsey said.

During the 2023 wildfires, many Albertans defied evacuation orders so they could stay and defend their properties.

"People ...especially when they're evacuated from their community, they really want to be involved," Loewen said. "Their lives are already disrupted and they want to be involved and help where they can. 

"We want to make sure that that opportunity's available for them."

Roughly 100 people signed up for the program in 2024 and approximately 80 signed up in 2025, according to a ministry spokesperson.

Despite the lower numbers, Loewen said the program will continue.

"There needs to always be an opportunity for people to help, and we appreciate the help," he said.

The Australian model

An ocean away, Australia leans heavily on volunteers to fight wildfires.

In the state of Victoria, the Country Fire Authority - a volunteer service - is responsible for responding to fires outside city centres, including bush fires.

Chief Officer Jason Heffernan said volunteers with the service receive nationally recognized training and have full workers' compensation coverage, but they do not receive financial compensation.

"A lot of people volunteer to look after their own property, their neighbour and their friends down the road," he said. 

"Other people do it because they have a need and a want to give back to community and feel that volunteering as part of their local fire service is a way to give back."

Heffernan suggested he believes the model has its merits.

"It works for the communities that we do have," he said. "We deploy interstate regularly. We have the ability to be able to pull that together. And I think there's lessons to be learned. 

"Don't discount the value that volunteering can bring."

Wildland fire ecologist raises concerns 

Firefighting can be dangerous. Two wildland firefighters were killed in Canada in 2024.

Wildland fire ecologist Bob Gray said he does not support volunteers working on wildfires.

"It's very, very dangerous work," he explained.

"You need people who are committed, who are going to make a career out of it, and you need to pay them for that. You need to compensate them for the risk they're putting themselves into."

When speaking about Alberta's reservist model, Gray said he has concerns about the length of training being a day and a half.

"That is not enough," he said. "You're putting people at risk. You're potentially creating an incident inside of an incident if you don't have trained, physically fit, qualified people on the fire line.

"They won't recognize the dangers [like] being able to understand fire behaviour, understanding actions and reactions."

Gurnsey said he believes local residents can bring valuable experience to a firefight, such as intimate knowledge of a region and a vested interest in their community.

While he acknowledged the possible dangers, he said people should be allowed to decide for themselves if they want to help. 

Gurnsey added he believes the additional manpower helps in a country as vast as Canada.

"I'm not encouraging recklessness," he said. 

"Hopefully people can be wise. But you should be allowed the decision whether or not you fight for your place, for your neighbours, for your livelihood."

Other provinces in Canada are also exploring the use of volunteer firefighters.

According to the Interagency Forest Fire Centre, nearly eight million hectares have burned to date in Canada this wildfire season.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-9923-RSCJ-F2C1-00000-00Felipe VI thanks the 'admirable' and 'supportive' work of the fire-fighting troops in Ourense2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisFelipe VI thanks the 'admirable' and 'supportive' work of the fire-fighting troops in Ourense


Verín - Felipe VI has addressed this Thursday to the troops of the means that have acted against the fires in Ourense to thank them on behalf of all Spain for the admirable, professional and supportive work they have done during these weeks of continuous work, and has also expressed a message of hope for recovery after the fire.


The king and queen, accompanied by the third vice-president and minister for Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge, Sara Aagesen, arrived this Thursday in Verín (Ourense) to see first hand the damage caused by the forest fires in the Galician province and to greet the troops who participated in the extinction tasks.
After landing by helicopter in Verín, in their first stop in the province of Ourense they visited the Coordination Center of the Forest District XIV, where they arrived after 12:30 pm, late on schedule.
There they have been received with applause by some residents of the area and have greeted the authorities, including the President of the Xunta, Alfonso Rueda; the Regional Minister of Rural Environment, María José Gómez, the delegate of the Government, Pedro Blanco; as well as the mayors of the Ourense towns of Verín and Monterrei, Gerardo Seoane and José Luis Suárez, respectively. A calmer situation
Felipe VI and Doña Letizia have accessed inside the center and have gone to the control room, where the head of the Provincial Fire Service of Ourense, Sandra Martinez, has offered some explanations about the devices of firefighting.
Later, the King and Queen went to the vehicle shed, where they greeted some of the members of different emergency teams that have developed their work these days.
Specifically, they greeted forest agents of the Xunta de Galicia, members of the Brigades of Reinforcement of Forest Fires (Brif), firefighters from the park of Verin and 112 teams, members of the National Police, Civil Protection and Civil Guard and military Brilat and UME, as well as the representative of Portugal of the National Authority for Emergency and Protection, Armando Ribeiro.
Apart from being interested in the health of all the injured, Felipe VI has made a very, very special, very grateful and emotional recognition to all those who have worked to fight the fire and prevent especially the human damage, as well as material damage to heritage and nature.
Although now the situation in Galicia is calmer, the monarch has urged not to lower our guard because the risk is not over, so he has recommended caution and be alert and prepared in case of new fires.
Queen Letizia also addressed a few words to the media deployed, to whom she expressed her gratitude, but also understanding for all the difficulties they have had to go through and that only they know. With the mayors
The King and Queen also greeted the mayors of the municipalities affected by the fire, among them the mayors of Castrelo do Val, Cualedro, A Gudiña, Laza, Oímbra, Viana do Bolo, Vilardevós, Vilariño de Conso, Ríos, as well as those of Verín and Monterrei.
Subsequently, they moved by caravan to Montes, in the municipality of Cualedro, where they visited a livestock farm and met with the owners of various farms, such as a poultry farm affected by the fire.
Around 2:30 p.m. they went to the last stop of their visit to the area, to the village of Medeiros, in the municipality of Monterrei, where they were also cheered and applauded by the neighbors.
In total, more than 96,000 hectares, according to data from the Xunta, have burned in forest fires this August, making 2025 the year with the largest area burned in Galicia this century. Visiting this Friday areas affected by the Jarilla fire
The King and Queen of Spain will visit this Friday several areas of the Jerte and Ambroz valleys in Cáceres affected by the Jarilla forest fire, considered the most virulent in the most recent history of Extremadura, which devastated 17,350 hectares.
The King and Queen want to know first hand the damages suffered and the needs of the affected neighbors, as well as to show their gratitude to all the teams that have contributed to fight the fire and protect the population, as explained by the Royal House in its press release.
Felipe VI and Doña Letizia will begin their visit to the municipality of Rebollar (Jerte valley), whose 200 residents were evicted, and then move to Cabezabellosa, in the region of Trasierra-Tierras de Granadilla, which links with the Ambroz valley.
The inhabitants of the Ambroz valley also had to abandon their homes, a measure which was also taken in Jarilla and Villar de Plasencia, as well as in isolated houses in Navaconcejo, Cabezuela del Valles and Jerte.
The visit will end in Hervás, in the heart of the Ambroz valley, whose inhabitants were confined.

urn:contentItem:6GN9-MC23-RYTH-N2T2-00000-00Visible from space: Vesuvius fire has three fronts still active, firefighters continue battle2025-08-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisVisible from space: Vesuvius fire has three fronts still active, firefighters continue battle

Satellite photos show the column of smoke rising from the Vesuvius National Park all the way over the Bay of Naples. Three firefronts remain active. Canadairs, helicopters and dozens of volunteer teams remain deployed.

The fire that broke out on Friday night in the Mount Vesuvius National Park continues to burn. The extremely high column of smoke produced by the fire in the national park is also visible from space. Satellite photos showing the Gulf of Naples with a long white plume rising from one side of the volcano have gone viral on the web, demonstrating the severity of the fire and the extent of the fire front.

According to information from the Prefect of Naples, Michele di Bari, at the end of a meeting of the Rescue Coordination Centre, there are still three active fronts: the Valle del Gigante towards Monte Somma, where the Canadair firefighting aircraft are operating, the southern slope of the crater, where regional Civil Protection helicopters are battling the flames. And the Vicinale area, where last night's wind rekindled the flames, which were tackled by ground teams.

The public prosecutor's office in Nola (Naples), which is responsible for the area, has opened a file to clarify the origin of the fire that is bringing one of the country's landscape and cultural symbols to its knees. According to what has been learnt so far, there no suspects and no crime hypotheses have been identified so far, pending the report that will be presented by the Carabinieri foresters.

Mobilised by the DPC, 23 civil protection volunteer teams from various parts of Italy are heading to Vesuvius Park to reinforce the response to the fire emergency. (1/2)

Since the early hours of Sunday, 6 Canadairs and 4 helicopters have been involved, in addition to 15 teams of Civil Protection volunteers mobilised by an extraordinary decree of the Minister of Civil Protection and Sea Policies, at the request of the Campania Region. The Fire Brigade has reinforced its presence with two forest fire-fighting modules from Tuscany and Marche and reinforcement teams from Benevento and Salerno.

On the health and logistical front, the mayors of the four worst hit municipalities have activated the Municipal Operations Centres and a fixed 24-hour medical station in Terzigno. The Asl Napoli 1 Centro has made the residence of the Ospedale del Mare available to host volunteers from other regions.

On the environmental and economic front, Italian farmers' group Coldiretti is reporting extensive damage to the Lacryma Christi DOP vine cultivation right on the eve of the grape harvest, as well as to the Pellecchiella apricot and Pomodorino del Piennolo DOP tomato cultivations. Also at risk are agritourism sites and tasting routes, with a very hard impact on local tourism and agriculture.

Legambiente report: 56,263 hectares already up in smoke in Italy

The seriousness of the situation is part of an alarming national context: according to Legambiente's report Italia in fumo (Italy in smoke), between 1 January and 31 July 2025 there were 851 fires for a total of 56,263 hectares burnt, already exceeding the surface area affected in all of 2024. In particular, over 18,700 hectares of Natura 2000 areas were destroyed in 253 fire episodes, confirming a trend defined as "chronic" by the association, which has launched an appeal to safeguard Italy's natural heritage.

urn:contentItem:6GH3-56V3-RXP3-93WR-00000-00Spain, Portugal, and Greece battle wildfires as heat wave is expected to last for days2025-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSSpain, Portugal, and Greece battle wildfires as heat wave is expected to last for daysSUMAN NAISHADHAMAssociated PressMADRID

MADRID (AP) — Firefighters in Spain, Portugal and Greecebattled ongoing wildfires Friday, an important religious holiday in all three countries, as persistent hot, dry conditions challenged efforts to contain the blazes.

Spain was fighting 14 major fires, according to Virginia Barcones, general director of emergency services. Temperatures were expected to climb over the weekend.

“Today will once again be a very tough day, with an extreme risk of new fires,” Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez wrote on X.

The national weather agency AEMET warned of extreme fire risk in most of the country, including where the largest blazes were burning in the north and west. A heat wave which brought temperatures exceeding 40 degrees Celsius (104 Fahrenheit) on several days this month was expected to last through Monday.

Fires in the Galicia region forced the closure of several highways. The high speed rail line connecting it to Spain's capital, Madrid, remained suspended.

The fires in Spain this year have burned 158,000 hectares or 610 square miles, according to the European Union’s European Forest Fire Information System. That is an area roughly as big as metropolitan London.

The wildfires raged on Friday as many European countries celebrated a religious holiday devoted to the Virgin Mary, known in Catholic countries like Spain and Portugal as the Feast of the Assumption.

In Portugal, nearly 4,000 firefighters were battling fires on Friday. Seven major fires were active. Authorities extended the state of alert until Sunday as high temperatures were expected to last through the weekend.

The Portuguese government on Friday requested assistance from the EU’s civil protection mechanism, a firefighting force that European countries in need can call upon. A day before, Spain received two Canadair water bomber aircraft after requesting EU help to tackle blazes for the first time ever.

In the past week, Greece, Bulgaria, Montenegro and Albania have also requested help from the EU’s firefighting force to deal with forest fires. The force has already been activated as many times this year as all of last year's fire season.

On Friday, a wildfire in Greece burned out of control for a fourth day on the island of Chios, prompting several more overnight evacuations.

Two water-dropping planes and two helicopters were operating in the north of the island in the eastern Aegean Sea, where local authorities said a lull in high winds was helping firefighters early Friday.

Following a series of large fires in western Greece earlier this week, the fire service was on alert Friday outside Athens and nearby areas in the south of the country where adverse weather conditions elevated the fire risk.

The spiritual leader of the world’s Orthodox Christians Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew expressed solidarity on Friday with the victims of wildfires in southern Europe during prayers on a day that is also important for Orthodox Christians and known as the Dormition of the Virgin Mary.

Scientists say that climate change is exacerbating the frequency and intensity of heat and dryness in parts of Europe, making the region more vulnerable to health impacts and wildfires.

The burning of fossil fuels like coal, gas and coal releases heat-trapping gasses that are the primary driver of climate change.

Europe has been warming twice as fast as the global average since the 1980s, according to the EU’s Copernicus Climate Change Service.

The EU monitoring agency says that 2024 was the hottest year on record both globally and in Europe, which experienced its second-highest number of ‘heat stress’ days.

___

AP writer Derek Gatopoulos contributed from Athens.

urn:contentItem:6GPB-W4N3-RSBK-54SM-00000-00The high-stakes plan to save Melbourne's drinking water from the next big bushfire2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisThe high-stakes plan to save Melbourne's drinking water from the next big bushfireAdam Carey

A plan involving the strategic placement of large nets in Melbourne's key water catchments aims to save the city's pristine water supply from a major bushfire.

Giant metallic nets will be strung across several creeks in the mountain forests from where most of Melbourne's water is sourced to save the city's supply from bushfire contamination that could render it undrinkable for up to a year.

Melbourne Water has been warned that a significant fire is likely to occur around the city's water catchments in coming years and when it does, burnt debris could pollute the supply for three to 12 months, forcing millions of people to boil tap water to make it safe to drink.

Link to Image

Joe Armao

More than 60 per cent of Melbourne's water is sourced from a chain of reservoirs in the mountain ranges east of Melbourne, which are off-limits to the public to keep the water supply pristine.

The catchments have long provided Melburnians with some of the purest tap water in the country, says professor Stuart Khan, head of the School of Civil Engineering at the University of Sydney and an expert on water infrastructure.

"One of the great things about Melbourne - it's a great thing and a vulnerability - is that you have that really pristine catchment, which is all forested, which means that there's actually not very much water treatment in Melbourne," Khan said.

But Melbourne Water has received expert advice that a major fire is increasingly likely to burn in catchment areas and that when it does, debris, including ash, soil and rock, could pollute those reservoirs.

Bushfire is the biggest future threat to Melbourne's water supply, and climate change is raising the risk of a severe fire occurring, the advice says.

Fire burnt 6300 hectares of remote forest near the portal where water is released from the giant Thomson Dam to the Upper Yarra Reservoir in the Black Summer fires of 2019-20, and researchers calculated that 1200 tonnes of sediment was at risk of flowing into Melbourne's water supply at the time.

"The Catchment Management and Optimisation Project identified that a significant bushfire event in the Upper Yarra is likely to occur in the next 30 years, which could result in the water supply being off-line for up to 12 months due to debris contaminating the water storages," Melbourne Water said in documents submitted to the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water (DEECA).

Melbourne Water's proposed solution is to put debris flow nets in 35 sites where water begins to stream into the Upper Yarra Reservoir.

The reservoir is located about 100 kilometres east of Melbourne and has a capacity of more than 200,000 megalitres.

It is a key part of the "Silvan system", a chain of four reservoirs that provide more than 60 per cent of the city's water supply.

Melbourne Water hopes to begin the project late next year, but must get approval from DEECA before it can proceed.

It said in its application that studies had found that establishing debris flow nets in the Upper Yarra catchment after a fire "would help reduce turbidity following rainfall events and the potential for the Silvan system to be off-line and boiled water notices being required."

The nets would be installed in two phases. In the first phase, technicians would be helicoptered into the inaccessible terrain to install a series of eight-metre-deep anchor points spanning multiple creek channels upstream of the Upper Yarra Reservoir. The nets would only be installed after a fire and before any heavy rainfalls.

Australian National University distinguished professor David Lindenmayer co-authored a book on Melbourne's water catchments with Jim Viggers, who looked after the catchments for 25 years.

Lindenmayer says successive Victorian governments "have kicked a major own goal by allowing logging in some of their most important catchments" for many years.

Native forest logging was banned in Victoria last year. Tributaries of the Yarra, including the Muddy, Salvation and McMahons creeks, were logged before the ban in a state-run program that has increased the likelihood of a severe fire, according to research by Lindenmayer and others.

"Logged and regenerated forests are incredibly flammable for at least 40 years after the forest was regenerated," Lindenmayer said.

Link to Image

Jason South

He also urged authorities to put an end to back-burning operations in the catchments for the same reason.

"For those tall wet forests - mountain ash, alpine ash - which [are] the most high-yielding catchments, the last thing you want to be doing is prescribed burning," he said.

Sean Hanrahan, an executive manager at Melbourne Water, said bushfire risks to the water supply had been managed alongside Forest Fire Management Victoria for 150 years.

"The debris barrier project helps maintain safe, uninterrupted supply in the months following a major bushfire. Paired with logs, these barriers stop contamination post-fire," Hanrahan said.

Khan said the nets were a sensible solution tailored to the unique vulnerability of Melbourne's water supply.

"If you just look at it from a technical perspective, holding debris back in the catchment after a fire is definitely a sensible strategy to try and manage what could be a very significant risk to Melbourne's water supply," he said.

Melbourne Water has never issued a boiled water alert after a fire. The last such alert was issued in 2020 after a power outage at Silvan dam.

Sydneysiders came close to having to boil their drinking water in 2021 after a one-in-100-year flood caused the Warragamba Dam to spill over. But in 1998, they had three months of boiled water notices due to a cryptosporidium outbreak.

Last month, households in Frankston South were told to boil their water for three days after South East Water blamed the issue on a faulty valve.

People were told to boil water before drinking, mixing cold drinks, preparing food, making ice, brushing teeth and gargling. The advice was even extended to giving cooled, boiled water or bottled water to pets.

The Upper Yarra Reservoir, east of Melbourne, is vulnerable to contamination from a major bushfire.

Backburning in Melbourne's water catchments increases the risk of a severe fire, expert David Lindenmayer says.

AFP News

August 15th, 2025 ( International Business Times News - Delivered by Newstex )

All of Spain was on heatwave alert on Friday, while the weather agency warned that much of the country was at "very high to extreme risk" from wildfires.

The situation had improved for several other southern European countries, but Greece was still fighting fires on one Aegean island.

Much of Spain has already endured nearly two weeks of high temperatures, and on Friday the searing heat spread to Cantabria, which had so far been spared.

Temperatures in the northwestern region were forecast to pass 40C, said Aemet, the national weather agency. The risk of fires on Friday and over the weekend into Monday was "very high or extreme in most of the country", it added.

Spain has endured a devastating season of fires, with 157,501 hectares (389,193 acres) reduced to ashes since the start of the year, according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).

Yet that figure is still well short of 2022, when more than 306,000 hectares went up in smoke.

Three people have died during the fires, including two young volunteers in their thirties who lost their lives trying to put out a fire in the Castile and Leon area.

One of them, Jaime Aparicio Vidales, was buried in the town of Quintanilla de Florez, Zamora province, Castile and Leon, on Friday.

On Thursday morning, France sent two water-bombing planes to help try to douse the flames in the northwestern region, where a dozen fires were still raging.

The railway line between Madrid and the northwestern region of Galicia remained closed as well as some 10 main roads in the country.

Marco Raton, 35, works on a pig farm in Sesnandez de Tabara near one of the fires in Castile and Leon that forced several thousand people to flee their homes.

He said he and his friends did not think twice when they saw the fire arrive on Tuesday and grabbed "everything we had -- backpacks, fire bats and garden hoses -- put on appropriate clothing and went over to help".

"As soon as we arrived, we started seeing burned people being evacuated, a car on fire, a burning tractor, warehouses, garages," he told AFP, adding that he felt "helpless".

Raton said he thought there was "nothing left to burn" after devastating fires in the same region in 2022 but he said he was convinced that "this will continue to happen to us year after year".

Angel Roman, the mayor of Ferreruela, said he believed that fire breaks cleared of brush should be established around the villages.

"The countryside, if it's clean, can stop the fire," he added.

Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez's Socialist PSOE party and the conservative PP have clashed in recent days over the crisis, with regional administrations normally tasked with putting out forest fires.

The central government only intervenes in major incidents and can call on an emergency military unit, which has been in high demand as reinforcement.

The PP accuses the government of having cut the number of air assets, something the PSOE has denied, accusing some opposition leaders of staying on holiday while their regions burned.

Elsewhere in southern Europe, lower temperatures and reduced wind were helping to improve the situation in Greece and the Balkans, where rain was forecast in many parts of the region.

The most active was still on the Mediterranean island of Chios, in the northeastern Aegean Sea, where eight aircraft have been deployed to try to douse the flames.

The risk of fire remained high in the Attica region that includes the capital, Athens, and the southern Pelopponese peninsula, the Civil Protection agency warned on Friday.

In Albania, initial government estimates said thousands of cattle had been killed and 40 homes destroyed in just three days of wildfires.

urn:contentItem:6GH3-54T3-RSCX-P4KJ-00000-00Spain, Portugal, and Greece battle wildfires as heat wave is expected to last for days2025-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:55:48ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSSpain, Portugal, and Greece battle wildfires as heat wave is expected to last for daysSUMAN NAISHADHAMAssociated PressMADRID

MADRID — Firefighters in Spain, Portugal and Greecebattled ongoing wildfires Friday, an important religious holiday in all three countries, as persistent hot, dry conditions challenged efforts to contain the blazes.

Spain was fighting 14 major fires, according to Virginia Barcones, general director of emergency services. Temperatures were expected to climb over the weekend.

“Today will once again be a very tough day, with an extreme risk of new fires,” Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez wrote on X.

The national weather agency AEMET warned of extreme fire risk in most of the country, including where the largest blazes were burning in the north and west. A heat wave which brought temperatures exceeding 40 degrees Celsius (104 Fahrenheit) on several days this month was expected to last through Monday.

Fires in the Galicia region forced the closure of several highways. The high speed rail line connecting it to Spain's capital, Madrid, remained suspended.

The fires in Spain this year have burned 158,000 hectares or 610 square miles, according to the European Union’s European Forest Fire Information System. That is an area roughly as big as metropolitan London.

The wildfires raged on Friday as many European countries celebrated a religious holiday devoted to the Virgin Mary, known in Catholic countries like Spain and Portugal as the Feast of the Assumption.

In Portugal, nearly 4,000 firefighters were battling fires on Friday. Seven major fires were active. Authorities extended the state of alert until Sunday as high temperatures were expected to last through the weekend.

The Portuguese government on Friday requested assistance from the EU’s civil protection mechanism, a firefighting force that European countries in need can call upon. A day before, Spain received two Canadair water bomber aircraft after requesting EU help to tackle blazes for the first time ever.

In the past week, Greece, Bulgaria, Montenegro and Albania have also requested help from the EU’s firefighting force to deal with forest fires. The force has already been activated as many times this year as all of last year's fire season.

On Friday, a wildfire in Greece burned out of control for a fourth day on the island of Chios, prompting several more overnight evacuations.

Two water-dropping planes and two helicopters were operating in the north of the island in the eastern Aegean Sea, where local authorities said a lull in high winds was helping firefighters early Friday.

Following a series of large fires in western Greece earlier this week, the fire service was on alert Friday outside Athens and nearby areas in the south of the country where adverse weather conditions elevated the fire risk.

The spiritual leader of the world’s Orthodox Christians Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew expressed solidarity on Friday with the victims of wildfires in southern Europe during prayers on a day that is also important for Orthodox Christians and known as the Dormition of the Virgin Mary.

Scientists say that climate change is exacerbating the frequency and intensity of heat and dryness in parts of Europe, making the region more vulnerable to health impacts and wildfires.

The burning of fossil fuels like coal, gas and coal releases heat-trapping gasses that are the primary driver of climate change.

Europe has been warming twice as fast as the global average since the 1980s, according to the EU’s Copernicus Climate Change Service.

The EU monitoring agency says that 2024 was the hottest year on record both globally and in Europe, which experienced its second-highest number of ‘heat stress’ days.

___

AP writer Derek Gatopoulos contributed from Athens.
